body:
You must have downloaded a non-complete version. The final beta isn't finished uploading yet; it's possible that you downloaded it before the file was fully uploaded. How big was the .iso that you downloaded? If you downloaded the cached version, it should be at least 3.6 Gb, and if you downloaded the non-cached version, it should be at least 1.5 Gb. I recommend waiting until Wednesday 7/29/2015, when the official release of the beta will occur, before re-downloading the file. On a side note, where did you hear about Apricity OS?

Thanks,

The Apricity OS Team

Thank you for your kind reply, I downloaded the two iso's in the download page and both behaved the same way. Take your advice and I'll wait for the new release.

Thank you

Just a heads up that everything is ready a few days ahead of our official release, so if you want to download Apricity OS, you can.

Enjoy,

The Apricity OS Team

http://apricityos.com/iso/apricity_os-07.2015-beta.torrent appears to be 404ing and the other torrent does not have any seeders. i'll see if i can start seeding once the direct downloads have finished.

Fixed. Thanks so much.

The Apricity OS Team

At this time is only 64 bits, so I hope for 32-bit

Thank You

Sorry, but at the moment we have plans only for 64 bit support. We may add support for 32 bit machines in the future, but at least for the time being, we only have the resources to develop one version of Apricity OS.

Our sincere apologies,

The Apricity OS Team
Now I understand what happened, when I lower the iso was not clear to arqutectura, thank you, I will then try in another laptop.
Did i not format it properly? Used Rufus, with FAT32, the default, as the disk fs. Please help. Trying to install as replacement for Manjaro i3, which bricked itself on me out of the blue.

I have experienced this issue once in the past, and it was due to not waiting long enough for the liveusb to be written to. My preferred booting flash drive has this nice led that flashes when it's being written to, and even though my burning tool said it was done, the led was still flashing. I pulled it out before the led stopped flashing, and got this error message, so I left it in a minute longer when trying again. Another thing that could be causing this problem is a borked download. Did you run md5sum on the .iso? Also, just for note, which .iso did you download? 

Thanks,

The Apricity OS Team

I have experienced this issue once in the past, and it was due to not waiting long enough for the liveusb to be written. I tried making a USB bootable install using your torrented beta with cache. The md5sum checked out to be good. I just retried burning with both Rufus and UNetbootin (just in case) and allowed the USB to remain for some time each time after the write processes were complete.

In both examples I saw the same error as previously noted. Are there any commands I can type at the [rootfs /]# console to help debug this error? The notice recommends a manual fix. Is there any documentation on what that fix might be?

I have reproduced this issue with Rufus, so it probably also exists for UNetbootin. I am currently evaluating other Windows ISO writing tools to recommend in the installation instructions. At the moment, I'm leaning towards Win32 Disk Imager which can be found at sourceforge.net/projects/win32diskimager. This tool does not have the same issue Rufus (and possibly UNetbootin) has. Note that you may have to select '*.*' instead of '*.img' when selecting the Apricity OS .iso file.

I have reproduced this issue with Rufus and am no longer recommending it in the installation instructions. I am currently evaluating other Windows ISO writing tools to recommend in the installation instructions. At the moment, I'm leaning towards Win32 Disk Imager which can be found at sourceforge.net/projects/win32diskimager. This tool does not have the same issue Rufus (and possibly UNetbootin) has. Note that you may have to select '*.*' instead of '*.img' when selecting the Apricity OS .iso file.
Thanks! Will give that a try today. I do have the ability to use Linux software to write the USB I just knew that Rufus worked for my last Arch install.
Win32 Disk Imager worked in creating the bootable ISO USB image. Rufus and UNetbootin both failed. Thank you so much for your time.

Thanks so much for your encouragement! It really means a lot to us. ICE is a great tool and we're proud to include it in our distro.

We hope you enjoy using Apricity as much as we enjoy using ICE.

The Apricity OS Team.

Intermediate, consumer-level developer aspiree here. Spent literally the entire day trying to install Apricity, and you know what? It was <spoiler> damn </spoiler> well worth it. As small a feature as ICE is, I use the sites i iced about as often as my offline applications. Great  work everyone, and keep up the good work.
http://imgur.com/3RUltN0
You can use in a Os Linux in the Terminal: # dd if= name iso of=/dev/sd? (Name of usb)
Botee the iso from the usb, follow the steps of the installer, but gets stuck in Installing using the method "advanced"
Used imageusb https://en.opensuse.org/SDB:Create_a_Live_USB_stick_using_Windows and it worked so far.  Just took some time to write and verify

Check the log at /tmp/cnchi.log. My guess is that it's going to give you some form of a connection error. This would be because a slightly unreliable internet connection. The way we have gotten around issues such as this is by opening a chrome tab before the installer's going and just making sure that the machine is actively connected to the Internet by loading some website, like apricityos.com for example.
Great! Thanks for your input.

Look at /tmp/cnchi.log and the problem was a failure in the connection, essentially the problem was a delay in milliseconds to connect repositories, solve it by adding some data in /etc/resolv.conf.
Successful installation, excellent distro congratulate very beautiful and functional for the first time.
Update: Win32 disk imager confirmed as working on windows, and the customary dd if$ of$ on linux.

You need to format your /boot/efi partition as (use as) fat32. It should actually have fat32 in parentheses after /boot/efi in the mount checklist, although perhaps we should make it slightly clearer that this is indeed the required format of the partition.
Oh, it is required to set up grub even if I already have it setup via Ubuntu?
Unfortunately, the advanced partition manager does not at this time support using an existing bootloader. We are working on a fix for the August Beta.
Alright thanks!

We actually recommend using the larger iso with slower internet, as the smaller iso does not have a package cache. The more packages the installer has to download, the greater the probability that a package will fail to download especially with slower internet, either because of too many connection timeouts, or because of repeatedly corrupt downloads. Try downloading the cached iso even if it takes a little while.

What parameters did you use in the install? Did it give any errors at all? Also, if you try to run the install again, it would be very helpful if you could post the contents of /tmp/cnchi.log.

That's odd. Try running 'steam' from the command line and post the output here.

Right now, we don't have any plans for original multimedia or office solutions as we feel Gnome, VLC, and LibreOffice have done a great job with their projects. We think it might be more productive for us to put our development time elsewhere, like improving the stability of Apricity OS or working towards a fully responsive, wayland-based desktop environment.
We are working on including a Plymouth script with Apricity OS. I'm not quite sure what you're saying about icons and buttons, but perhaps a screenshot would help explain your issue.

In our experience, the 'Can't Install Necessary Packages' error occurs because of repeated timeouts when the installer is attempting to download updated packages. We have never seen this error occur when installing from the cached iso, although it is theoretically possible.

Just a few questions before I can help. First, what error message(s) do you get? Also, which iso did you download? Are you booting it with uefi or legacy? If you don't know, you can check by simply seeing if the installer gives you the option to select a bootloader (grub2 or gummiboot). If it does, you are booting it with uefi. Finally, how strong is your WiFi connection? It would also be great if you could post the contents of /tmp/cnchi.log.

Thanks,

Alex
My desktop resolution is 1366x768 @ 60Hz.

I believe this is a problem with your monitor and not with the bootable usb drive. There's another thread here that you can check out, and it seems that this is something people have experienced in the past. I'm not very knowledgeable in monitors and their issues, but if you look around the web you will find solved cases of this problem. Hope this helps, Alex
Both ISOs are now mirrored on SourceForge. The cached one can be found here, and the noncached one can be found here.

My monitor is actually working fine for everything, its just that when i select the option to install ApricityOS it checks some stuff with a black screen and then when the installation is about to start my monitor goes blank and displays the above message. So if there would be a method to install the OS by changing the resolution it uses for booting it would be really helpful. Or should i try the cached version?

How far does it get in trying to boot the installer? Do you actually get to a graphical environment with a wallpaper and a dock and a window with installation buttons? If it doesn't, what kind of screen do you get? Is it a white screen with the Apricity OS logo at the top and a list of booting options below? Do you only ever get a black screen with a few words in the upper left? Also, do you know if you're booting with uefi or legacy?

I get the white screen with the ApricityOS logo after which i select the option to boot apricity then i get a black screen with the commands, where it checks for kvm and stuff after which i get this screen. Thanks for replying so fast :)

The white screen means you're booting under legacy boot, which I believe tries to force a relatively low resolution. If your machine supports booting from uefi, I would try booting with that as it should allow your monitor to run at its native resolution. You can google your particular computer to see if it supports booting from uefi. If not, I'll try to think of another solution. The live usb should automatically select an appropriate resolution, and I'm not quite sure why it's not in your particular case.
OK ill try that in some time. I hope it works, thanks for all the help :)
OK ill try that in some time. I hope it works, thanks for all the help :)

I do not get any error messages I am just unable to continue with installation. I downloaded the 64-bit cached iso from the home page and mounted it to a USB. I believe I am booting with legacy. My WiFi is 37 mega-bits down and full connection. Here is my cnchi.log --> "http://pastebin.com/F2J8EWRz" .

Two things. First, did you check that the download was complete with md5sum? Also, I do see a few connection errors in the log, so it would be a good idea to verify that your connection really exists by opening apricityos.com in chrome.

I have no idea how to check md5sum, if you could refer me to a guide I could. I have been using apricity to reply to this post so my connection is there. Also here are some screenshots from my installation if they help: here I choose to edit partition table because I don't want to erase my windows partition http://i.imgur.com/hsVxjld.jpg and here is what my partition table currently is http://i.imgur.com/MEkSH4p.jpg   In the top right I am unable to continue because the arrow is faded.

Oh, that's actually really simple. You have to make a root partition with the free space. Double click the row that says free space, use it as ext4, and mount it at / (also be sure the format box is checked).

Wow, I am sorry for wasting your time, I should've seen that is was root (/) because the whole time I was looking for /root. As I said I am very new to linux but thank you for the help.

-DogInSpace
No problem! We're just glad to have another user. Don't hesitate to ask any other questions you may have.

I may have an answer to this, but it starts with a question.  Do you run AMD graphics?  Steam has a weird bug in it where, if you run AMD graphics, you have to install Steam, run Steam for the first time and update it, then install the proprietary AMD (Catalyst) driver.  It works normally after that.  I don't know why this is so, but I've had the same issue on my laptop, which has AMD graphics and I found that answer on the Steam forums.

I'm trying to install Apricity in second time. Now using a flash drive also with cashed version. Why an installer doesn't try to come back the installation where it was interrupted? Or reconnect?
Easiest solution for now is try to restart installation. I installed Apricity on the 7 time.
It's just in beta stage and was created a few times ago. I think guys will make some demo when OS will in final release.
Check log file for some errors. It stores in /tmp/cnchi.log
Too late, I already rebooted.

3rd attempt to install, now it's not moving past 4%.  Downloading linux-headers 4.1.4-1.  The log file doesn't show any errors, it's simply not proceeding forward.  I'd thought maybe my earlier error was an issue with the DVD I'm using (it's a DVD-RW, and they can go bad) but I got past this point earlier, so I don't think that's it.  I'm going to try one more time and, if it doesn't work, I'm moving on to something else.

Another failure.  This time, I got to 100% and it gave me the cryptic "can't continue" message with no explanation.  It's a beta OS with a beta installer, so these things are bound to happen.  I think I'll just wait for the next release to see if any of these issues are ironed out.  I'd rather spend an hour or so downloading another 4GB .iso than the two plus hours I've wasted on failed installations.

The installer cannot erase the disk twice in a row without a reboot in-between. The advanced partitioner works fine without a reboot, although it does throw some harmless errors. We are working on fixing some of the errors in the installer for the August Beta releasing towards the end of this month.

We're actually going to ship the August Beta with a much more stable installer, but for now you can try running sudo pacman -Syy before starting the install. Could you post the full cnchi log? We've never run into this issue before and it could be useful to find a workaround for issue for anybody installing before the end of the month.

Yeah, the ping from overseas can sometimes exceed the 1000 ms maximum specified by pacman. That's why we wanted to start mirroring the repository on sourceforge, but it seems that that did not solve everything. If you're having issues, you could try using the above instructions to switch to the sourceforge mirror. Alternatively, we will likely post an alpha with the new installer early next week. I can post a link to it in this thread when it's up.

Update: retried 3 times all with the same result: after the 100% integrity checking it says "Can't install necessary packages. Cnichi can't continue." Help, please. I'm getting desperate here, it's 10 times i'm trying to get it to work and still no response. I love this distro but the installer is making me go mad.

Here's the thing: the installer that we included in the July Beta tries to do a netinstall, and the sheer number of packages and updates it has to download makes it more and more likely as time goes on that one of the downloads will be corrupted. We're working on a completely different installer that installs Apricity completely differently, and as soon as its ready, even before we have the final iso built, we'll post instructions for how to use it from the existing ISOs.
Ok guys, that's some awesome news. May i ask for ETA? I wanna try this beautiful OS as soon as possible, it really enchanted me! Congratulation for creating such a good distro!
We're hoping to post instructions within a couple days and the August Beta early next week.
PS: I have checked the md5 of the downloaded isos and the integrity is at 100%

Do you have access to another operating system (not windows) from which you could try to write the iso? We have never seen this happen with win32 disk imager. Is it possible that that application itself is somehow corrupted? What version of windows are you running?

I am running Windows 10. I have access to a Mac running Yosemite and will try that. Also I was reading around that the new installer will be released with the August beta. Is there any update on when that will be released if you don't mind me asking?
Early next week is our target.

Translations on linux in general are rather fragmented. Some applications, like the Apricity installer and LibreOffice, will have excellent language support, while others will have almost none. Apricity should be perfectly usable, though some included applications may not have great translations. As for your bootmanager, the new installer that we're including in the soon-to-be-released August Beta lets you select a boot partition, although to get grub working as it should with your bootmanager, you may need to execute some additional commands. See this article for more information on partition boot sectors with Arch based distros, and don't hesitate to contact us if you have any other questions.

UPDATE: Unetbootin on Mac does not work, nor does using the restore function through Disk Utility. In fact, it was almost impossible to restore through Disk Utility. I will update when the dd function finishes and I boot the USB.

The only way to write Apricity to a usb from a Mac that we have found to work has been dd, using the tutorial linked from the installation instructions. Lack of support for unetbootin is a known issue that we're investigating.

UPDATE 2: I used the dd function on the distro I have used before (elementary OS) and it didn't work. I used the same command and ISO on a Mac and it works nownow... Strange. So confused but ready to install.

Update: .....the win32 software literally broke my USB drive. Seriously? In my partition manager, it shows 14 GB unallocated and I can't actually do anything with it. Wonderful. I guess I won't be attempting to install until someone else replies with a better solution. I refuse to use this software anymore.

I can confirm that Apricity OS doesn't work with Universal USB Installer. If you feel comfortable trying one more application, usbwriter works perfectly with the Apricity OS ISO. Also keep in mind that we're planning to release the August Beta within a couple days.

I downloaded the beta but USBWriter gives me the same problem as before. It creates a 30.9mb partition and calls it ARCH_EFI and copies only the "efi" and "loader" folders. This is on Windows 10. I am currently trying with Universal USB Installer and will post the results soon.

Even though the original poster didn't return, I have further information on this subject that I feel other users may find useful, so I'm going to post it.

Steam is a 32-bit program.  Even when you install the "64-bit" version, it's still 32-bit.  Therefore, it has 32-bit needs.  The reason it won't start by default is because it needs the 32-bit version of your graphics driver installed.  For details as to what packages need to be installed for your specific card, look at this page:

https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Xorg#Driver_installation

In my case, I had to install lib32-nvidia-340xx-libgl in order for Steam to start on my Nvidia based system.  Once I did, it started right up and started updating.  Prior to that, it did nothing and running it from a terminal returned a driver error.  Also, in order to have sound on a 64-bit system, you need to install lib32-alsa-plugins.  This is necessary no matter what your architecture.  Further tips and troubleshooting for Steam on Arch can be found here:

https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Steam

Anyway, I hope other users find this information useful.  I know I did, because I'm now running Steam on Apricity OS.  (it's currently updating)

There are two things that could solve this. The easiest works only if you have a Broadcom BCM43142 card, and the slightly more difficult one works if you have almost any other type of Broadcom card. The easy solution is to simply run "sudo modprobe brcmsmac" from a terminal, and the slightly more difficult one is to find an external wireless adapter, connect to the internet with it, then run "sudo pacman -R broadcom-wl-dkms broadcom-wl && sudo pacman -S broadcom-wl" from a terminal.

Any changes that have been made to packages other than the installer can be installed from the Pamac package manager. We chose Arch Linux because we wanted our users to always have access to the most up-to-date software, and we wanted to avoid the hassle that other popular Linux distributions (Linux Mint...) force their users to go through when a new version comes out. The idea is that with Apricity OS, you can install it once and never again have to look at an Apricity iso, live image, or installer. We also chose Arch Linux because of the AUR, which gives Arch Linux a uniquely centralized repository for everything that's not in the official ones. Additionally, because we use the official Arch Linux repositories, we have access to the huge community of testers and troubleshooters that make sure packages are actually stable and can actually be upgraded without fear of breaking something. That said, it is still important to update regularly, as if a system falls too far behind, it does become more likely that even a thoroughly tested package may break something, as unstable packages are usually tested on up-to-date systems. This is why the Pamac graphical package manager and updater checks for updates so frequently and pushes update notifications as soon as there's any update available. We're also working on creating a checkbox somewhere in the Pamac settings that would enable automatic updates in the background, leaving the user to (slightly) more manually update only packages installed from the AUR.

Apricity OS began as a small project (thought up by myself) to make an Arch Linux iso that would make installing and setting up Arch Linux just the way we like it much easier. It was never meant to be a published distribution: it was just something to improve our lives a little bit. Eventually, seeing how much work it took to make said iso, we decided to polish it a little bit and publish it. The name "Apricity" means "The Warmth of the Sun on a Winter Day". Its etymology has to do with wishing for April while it's still cold out. Myself and one other team member were looking for depreciated yet beautiful-sounding words when we stumbled upon "Apricity". We didn't decide then-and-there to name the project Apricity OS, but we did tentatively start calling it that and the name just stuck (especially after we made the wordmark). Our goal is to create an operating system that works really well out of the box, looks good enough to steal people from Apple and Microsoft, supports the widest possible range of regularly updated apps (hence the Arch Linux base), and has great support for Windows apps as soon as you install it. We also want to help people use their favorite web apps more easily, which is why we included ICE. Going forward, we have some really exciting developments that we can't talk about just yet but that we think you'll love.

Cheers,

Alex, Lead Dev of Apricity OS

"gsettings set org.gnome.shell enabled-extensions "['user-theme@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com', 'alwayszoomworkspaces@jamie.thenicols.net', 'mediaplayer@patapon.info', 'caffeine@patapon.info', 'scroll-workspaces@gfxmonk.net', 'dash-to-dock@micxgx.gmail.com', 'suspend-button@laserb', 'topIcons@adel.gadllah@gmail.com', 'places-menu@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com', 'drive-menu@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com', 'remove-dropdown-arrows@mpdeimos.com', 'Move_Clock@rmy.pobox.com']"". Keep in mind that you can paste in gnome-terminal with ctrl-shift-v. The other thing you can do to reset Apricity to its default configuration is remove the file found at ~/.firstrun.ran. This can be done by opening the file browser application, hitting ctrl-h to show hidden files, right-clicking the file called .firstrun.ran, and selecting "Move to Trash". There are a few things wrong with the partitioning scheme you created. The easiest thing you can do is go back to windows, open up Disk Manager, create a 120Gb simple volume labeled "ReplaceMe", and be sure you can recognize it from its position in the partition table of your SSD. Then, boot into the Apricity OS live image, and when the installer asks how you'd like to partition your disks, tell it you want to replace an existing partition, and select the 120Gb partition you just created. When the installer finishes, reboot your system and you should be good to go.

beta2 didn't fix it for me (nvidia 970). In addition when I tried installing nvidia-libgl and uninstalled bumblebee the computer locked and subsequent apricity boot attempts gave an "oh no something has gone wrong" screen.

Once you get to the "oh no something has gone wrong" screen, you can switch to a command-line login by pressing CTRL-ALT-F3. From there, login, and try running "su -c 'pacman -S bumblebee && systemctl enable bumblebeed && systemctl start bumblebeed'". It may be that bumblebee is just not being enabled properly after the installation (nobody on the Apricity OS Team has a discrete Nvidia card so we can only test this through you). Bumblebee provides all of the necessary nvidia-libgl packages and actively switches to the necessary one depending on what card is plugged in, so fixing this problem should be as simple as enabling the bumblebee daemon. 

If this still doesn't fix the scaling issue (but lets you log in to a graphical session normally), then it might be a GNOME issue. To test that, you can do one of two things. First, you can just reboot and see if the GDM login screen also has a weird aspect ratio. Alternatively, you can install the xfce4 group, then reboot and, after selecting your user but before entering your password, select XFCE from the cog wheel dropdown menu. After you do that you can enter your password and login. If that also has a weird aspect ratio, then it's definitely an issue with the driver. Otherwise, it's probably something with GNOME.

What if you run "su -c 'pacman -S broadcom-wl-dkms && rmmod b43 2>/dev/null && rmmod b43legacy 2>/dev/null && rmmod ssb 2>/dev/null && rmmod bcm43xx 2>/dev/null && rmmod brcm80211 2>/dev/null && rmmod brcmfmac 2>/dev/null && rmmod brcmsmac 2>/dev/null && rmmod bcma 2>/dev/null && modprobe wl && /usr/bin/depmod -a'" (without the double quotation marks around the command)?

If that works, run "sudo gedit /etc/modules-load.d/wl.conf" and put the following in the file, making sure to save it afterwards:

# Load wl at boot
wl

After that, just reboot.

To do exactly what you're describing, run "sudo gedit /etc/modules-load.d/brcmsmac.conf" and put the following in the file, making sure to save it afterwards:

# Load brcmsmac at boot
brcmsmac

After that, just reboot. However, it's usually a better idea to run "su -c 'pacman -S broadcom-wl-dkms && sudo gedit /etc/mules-load.d/wl.conf'" and put the following in the file, making sure to save it afterwards:

# Load wl at boot
wl

Again, you should reboot afterwards.

Grub still didn't get properly installed (it should have thrown an error, I'm not sure why it didn't) because you didn't make a fat32 formatted /boot/efi partition. A swap partition is not required, although it is recommended.
What do you suggest I do now? Re-install the whole OS or just create a new partition and somehow install Grub if it's possible that way?

Unfortunately it isn't possible to install just grub with the Apricity OS installer in its current state, so I would recommend that you reinstall. Make sure that you have a root partition of at least 10Gb, a /boot/efi partition formatted as fat32, and it is recommended to create a swap partition as well as a home partition, although it is not required. Making a home partition would mean that if, for whatever reason, you needed you needed to reinstall Apricity, you could do so without having to manually copy your files to an external device, re-partition your drive, then copy them back over. If you want to do that, make a partition as big as you think all of your files will take up, format it as ext4, and mount it at /home. 

Hope this helps, 

Alex

The last thing the archwiki recommends is to install the linux-lts package and subsequently update grub by running "su -c 'os-prober && grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg'". After that finishes, you should have one or two new entries in your bootloader that are marked with "LTS". If you boot with those, Apricity will use a more stable version of the Linux kernel which, according to the archwiki, may solve the driver's instability with certain routers.

This seems to be a bug in Gnome. You can try this workaround:

Edit the file:
/etc/pulse/default.pa
and comment out (with an # at the beginning of the line) the following line:
#load-module module-bluetooth-discover
now edit the file:
/usr/bin/start-pulseaudio-x11
and after the lines:
   if [ x”$SESSION_MANAGER” != x ] ; then
        /usr/bin/pactl load-module module-x11-xsmp “display=$DISPLAY session_manager=$SESSION_MANAGER” > /dev/null
    fi
add the following line:
    /usr/bin/pactl load-module module-bluetooth-discover
This way the Pulse audio’s Bluetooth modules will not be downloaded at boot time but after x11 is started.

After this (and a reboot) run "pacmd ls" and "pacmd set-card-profile index a2dp_sink", replacing "index" with the index of your bluetooth device.

The best way to enable catalyst support is to run "sudo gedit /etc/pacman.conf", adding the following lines above the apricity-core repository:

[catalyst]
Server = http://catalyst.wirephire.com/repo/catalyst/$arch
## Mirrors, if the primary server does not work or is too slow:
#Server = http://70.239.162.206/catalyst-mirror/repo/catalyst/$arch
#Server = http://mirror.rts-informatique.fr/archlinux-catalyst/repo/catalyst/$arch
#Server = http://mirror.hactar.bz/Vi0L0/catalyst/$arch

After that, run "su -c 'pacman -Syy && pacman -S catalyst-hook catalyst-utils catalyst-libgl opencl-catalyst lib32-catalyst-utils lib32-catalyst-libgl lib32-opencl-catalyst'". Then, if you have only one monitor run "sudo aticonfig --initial". Otherwise, if you have two monitors and want to use both of them, run "sudo aticonfig --initial=dual-head --screen-layout=above". After that, run "sudo gedit /etc/modprobe.d/modprobe.conf" and add the following line:

blacklist radeon

Then you need to add "nomodeset" to your kernel parameters. To do this, run "sudo gedit /etc/default/grub" and change the line

GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash"

so that it looks like this:

GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash nomodeset"

After that, run "sudo grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg" and reboot. If all goes well, you should be greeted with graphics loaded using the proprietary driver.

I'm going to re-install the whole OS, but I'm not sure I get what you mean with the partitions. How many partitions should I create? And why?

These are the partitions you should create:

EFI partition, around 200Mb, formatted as fat32, mounted at /boot/efi.

Root partition, at least 10Gb, formatted as ext4, mounted at /.

Home partition, as big as you think all your files and pictures will take up, formatted as ext4, mounted at /home. 

Swap partition (optional, acts as RAM when that's running low), around the total size of your RAM, formatted as linuxswap, not mounted. 

Hope this helps.

I solved my problem and later I have  found a easy solution.
$ sudo pacman -S hostapd
 $ yaourt -S create_ap 

You can find information here https://github.com/oblique/create_ap.

Examples:
No passphrase (open network):
./create_ap wlan0 eth0 MyAccessPoint
WPA + WPA2 passphrase:
./create_ap wlan0 eth0 MyAccessPoint MyPassPhrase
AP without Internet sharing:
./create_ap -n wlan0 MyAccessPoint MyPassPhrase
Bridged Internet sharing:
./create_ap -m bridge wlan0 eth0 MyAccessPoint MyPassPhrase
Internet sharing from the same WiFi interface:
./create_ap wlan0 wlan0 MyAccessPoint MyPassPhrase


PD: enp9s0 is eth0 and wlp8s0 is wlan0. You can see with this command : dmesg | grep wlan0.

Having done that, you can then copy over all of the files and directories from each of those partitions that you backed up with SBackup, and all things going well, you should boot into your old Apricity OS installation.

How can I install Apricity?

Assuming you're using the installer's advanced partitioner, you can either create a new partition that's around 200Mb, formatted as fat32, and mounted at /boot/efi with some of the free space you have available, or you can format your existing efi partition as fat32 and mount it at /boot/efi. Unfortunately the installer does not at this time support using existing bootloaders, so it does need to format an efi partition, be it new or old. Either way, in order to get back to Windows 10 after the installation completes, you'll have to first boot into your new Apricity installation and run the following command from a terminal window: "su -c 'os-prober && grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg'" (making sure not to forget the closing single quotation mark). After that, you should, upon booting, be presented with a Grub screen that has an option for booting into Apricity and an option for booting into Windows.

Oddly enough, this only happens when certain USB writing tools are used (Rufus and UNetbootin, for example). The temporary solution has been to tell people to use tools that don't have this issue, but it should be fixable. It seems to be rooted in the fact that UNetbootin and Rufus try to use their own bootloaders when they should just do a disk dump (arch-based distros tend to include bootloaders while Ubuntu-based ones tend not to).

One easy way to decrease system resource usage is to disable animations. This can be done from the Tweak Tool application. Otherwise, if you think something dramatically changed and want to investigate what's causing the bump in system resource usage, you can go to the processes tab of the System Monitor application and sort by memory usage. From there you can try to find what processes are eating up all your ram.

If normal reboot or poweroff works but take a suspiciously long time, then boot with the following debug options (press 'e' to edit kernel parameters while the Grub screen is showing):

systemd.log_level=debug systemd.log_target=kmsg log_buf_len=1M enforcing=0

Then, save the following script as /usr/lib/systemd/system-shutdown/debug.sh and make it executable:

#!/bin/sh
mount -o remount,rw /
dmesg > /shutdown-log.txt
mount -o remount,ro /

Then, just reboot and open the file at /shutdown-log.txt and look for any systemd timeouts.

Nothing is obvious there either. You could try logging in using a different desktop manager. LightDM is a recommended one, and you can install it with the command 

su -c 'pacman -S lightdm lightdm-gtk-greeter && systemctl disable gdm && systemctl enable lightdm'

Afterwards, you can try it with a reboot.

You can run that command as-is. Bash will interpret it as three commands.

Whoops, I forgot to tell you to enable the greeter in the conf file. Edit /etc/lightdm/lightdm.conf as root, and below the uncommented "[Seat:*]" line but above everything else, add "greeter-session=lightdm-gtk-greeter" (without quotation marks).

I had to use windows to edit the config. Found [Seat:*] and added greeter-session=lightdm-gtk-greeter right below it, but above all the other lines with # next to them.  Still get nothing. Still no login screen.

Alright, we can go back to what works, but this doesn't bring us any closer to figuring out what the issue is. You can re-enable GDM, the default Apricity OS desktop manager, by logging in with that TTY prompt that you're greeted with when you try to boot Apricity, and running "systemctl enable gdm".

Did you make sure that sound wasn't muted? The slider is in the upper-right menubar dropdown. If that's not the problem, also make sure it's not muted on the ALSA side by running alsamixer from a terminal window. If it says M below one of the sliders, that output is muted. If that doesn't return any results, let me know. It's really odd that headphones don't work but speakers do, as a much more frequently reported and documented error is the opposite. What if you try a different pair of headphones? Any change?
Oh, and you should disable lightdm with "systemctl disable lightdm".

Alright, wayland is up and running.  Thanks for trying to assist.  I will keep searching and post here if I figure something out.  I ran the following commands and got gdm running again.

sudo systemctl disable lightdm
sudo systemctl enable gdm
sudo systemctl stop lightdm
sudo systemctl start gdm

This is fascinating for several reasons. First, when the regular shell fails, it seems to fall back to Wayland, something I haven't seen before. Second, the regular shell and Wayland fail in exactly the way: they are killed by some other process that doesn't show up in the log. It's especially weird that it only shows up in VirtualBox, and even then only on some computers. My conclusion is that it's a bug in Gnome that might have arisen in the fresh version 3.18 and will hopefully be addressed in one of the point releases between 3.18 and 3.20. Thanks so much for putting so much effort into getting those logs, by the way.

It looks like might actually an issue in ACPI, the process that handles the actual brightness, volume, and touchpad modification. Do the brightness and volume sliders in the upper-right menubar dropdown still work? Also, what kind of computer do you have? This is likely an issue with your specific hardware since you're the only one reporting it.

I got those logs thusly: in the Live session after it borked with the 'Oh no!' screen, I went to the console (as you directed); then I mounted the virtual hdd that I'd attached /dev/sda1 as /mnt.  I copied those files to /mnt (/dev/sda1).  Then I rebooted with another Live session iso (in this case LXLE), remounted /dev/sda1 as /mnt, fired up a browser, fired up my email, created an email and attached the 2 files and sent the email to myself.  The rest is history.  I'm glad you got some essence of what was going on from them.  Also FYI here's a problem that is out there between GNOME 3.18 and Arch and LightDM...
http://itsfoss.com/fix-white-screen-login-arch-linux

Apricity OS does indeed use GRUB2. The easiest way to install Apricity is as follows:

1. On Windows, open up disk management, the Microsoft-developed partitioning tool that comes with all Windows 10 installations. 

2. Find your main Windows partition, right click it, and select resize. You should resize it by the amount of space you want to dedicate to Apricity (10Gb minimum).

3. Right click the free space that you just created by resizing your primary Windows partition, and make a new simple volume there named REPLACEME that takes up the entirety of the free space.

4. Download Apricity OS using the download link on apricityos.com

5. Download and install USBWriter (sourceforge.net/projects/usbwriter/)

6. Use USBWriter to write the Apricity ISO to your flash drive. Be careful here: you don't want to accidentally write it to the wrong storage device. 

7. Boot into that USB device.

8. Follow the instructions given by the installer to select your language, keymap, etc. 

9. When you get to the partitioning step, select the top option labeled Replace An Existing Partition, then select the NTFS partition that you created earlier.

10. Confirm the installation, then reboot into your new operating system.

Hope this helps,

Alex

If you want a desktop shortcut that will automatically run your shell scripts, you can put the executable in a permanent place and make a '.desktop' file that runs it. An example file can be found at ~/.config/autostart/firstrun.desktop. If you open a copy of that with gedit, you can replace the exec entry with the path to your script, save the new file wherever you want, and you should be able to double click it to run your script.

Oh,that's an error i also could not fix in the past.
The usual "NTFS is in an unsafe state and cannot be mounted as r/w" error.
You can use "Disks",choose your Windows partition,go to Options (the gears) and then "Edit Mount Options" and uncheck the "Automatic mount options".
Then go to this line:
nosuid,nodev,nofail,x-gvfs-show
and make it:
nosuid,nodev,nofail,x-gvfs-show,ro
and save.
After next reboot,your Windows/NTFS partition should be auto-mounted and accesible.
Also,make sure you've deactivated Fast Startup in Windows.

Does your BIOS have any option such as Trusted Boot, TPM, Secure Boot, or anything along those lines? If it does, turn it off. Windows 7 & Mint 17 will boot with this enabled, most other linux variants will hang when attempting to load the kernel (without a degree of configuration).

It sounds to me like you are referencing the start up menu, not the HP BIOS setup menu itself. ESC at boot usually gets you the former, F10 (or ESC and then F10) usually gets you the latter.

I may be wrong, but you might want to make sure just in case. If not, I would recommend booting into Windows 7 and (carefully) upgrading/re-flashing your BIOS as admin suggested before doing any more troubleshooting. I was able to replicate this problem on two different machines (in a few different ways) and fix it by changing TPM/Secure Boot and adjusting any compatibility options in the BIOS; which is why I suspect the BIOS upgrade solution worked for the fellow in the thread admin linked.

I also realized that my first solution was written as if you were using an already installed Grub bootloader, not a USB boot.  You can try adding those options I listed (but only either or, not both) in the USB bootloader in between 'quiet' and 'splash'  in that line of text. But I don't think this is a graphics issue at all, so I'd be really surprised if that helped.

— etnad

IF your wireless chipset is this: rtl8723be
This is how to fix it:

$ gksudo nautilus

Browse to folder /etc/modprobe.d/  

Open file: rtl8723be.conf   (IF it does not exist,CREATE it)

and paste this line:

options rtl8723be fwlps=N ips=N swlps=N swenc=Y disable_watchdog=Y


Save,exit and reboot.

Yes, I think so. But one is allowed to have 3 primary partitions+1 extended partition. But the extended partition can contain  several logical partitions , one of which you could install Apricity OS on. So if you could change one of your existing primary partitions to an extended partition and create a few logical ext.4 partitions within it, your problem would be solved. Take a look at the instructions for Gparted or a similar partion tool to clarify the matter. Perhaps another forum member will provide better help to you. Hope you succeed.

Run the following commands and it should repopulate your gpg keys. 
1 - sudo pacman-key --init archlinux
2 - sudo pacman-key --populate archlinux
3 - sudo pacman-key --refresh-keys

As for the apt to pacman translations:

sudo apt-get udpate; sudo pacman -Syy

sudo apt-get upgrade; sudo pacman -Su (hint: you can do both the update and the upgrade in one step with sudo pacman -Syu) 

sudo apt autoremove; sudo pacman -R $(pacman -Qdtq)

sudo apt clean; sudo pacman -Sc

Hope this helps

With Archlinux based distro don't use this command, but you can use Pacman -S  YourSoftware
or update commande Yaourt and make Yaourt -S YourSoftware. 
https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Yaourt

to add yaourt command you have to edit /etc/pacman.conf  using this command sudo nano /etc/pacman.conf
and add this lines 
[archlinuxfr]
SigLevel = Never
Server = http://repo.archlinux.fr/$arch

don't forget to uncomment  the MUtilib lines.
and finely update using pacman  -Syu and voilà you can use yaourt :)

I had a similar problem, I found that the keyserver was not working. I changed it to the MIT keyserver and it worked fine.
in /etc/pacman.d/gnupg/gpg.conf I had to change the keyserver to hkp://pgp.mit.edu
You of course need root to make this change, so just type this:
sudo gedit /etc/pacman.d/gnupg/gpg.conf      then change they keyserver ___... to hkp://pgp.mit.edu
there are probably other keyservers that work, but I trust MIT so that's what I changed it to.

sudo pacman -Syy nvidia bumblebee lib32-virtualgl lib32-nvidia-utils lib32-mesa-libgl
sudo gpasswd -a $USERNAME bumblebee
sudo systemctl enable bumblebeed.service
sudo reboot

After reboot test with:

64 bit.
optirun glxspheres64
32 bit. optirun glxspheres64


See more here: https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Bumblebee#Installing_Bumblebee_with_Intel.2FNVIDIA

Run the following commands and it should repopulate your gpg keys. 
1 - sudo pacman-key --init archlinux
2 - sudo pacman-key --populate archlinux
3 - sudo pacman-key --refresh-keys

As for the apt to pacman translations:

sudo apt-get udpate; sudo pacman -Syy

sudo apt-get upgrade; sudo pacman -Su (hint: you can do both the update and the upgrade in one step with sudo pacman -Syu) 

sudo apt autoremove; sudo pacman -R $(pacman -Qdtq)

sudo apt clean; sudo pacman -Sc

Hope this helps

Wow,that's a serious piece of hardware!
Please,get into your bios/uefi and take a look at these tabs:
1. Boot sequence>Boot list option>Check "Legacy" radio button
2.Advanced Boot Options>Check "Enable Legacy Option Roms" box
3.Secure Boot Enable>Check "Disabled" radio button
4.Post Behavior>Fastboot>Check "Thorough" radio button.

Also check the MD5 hash of your downloaded ISO image (before you create your installation media).
Sometimes,something as silly as this can prevent success.
Your hardware is extremely powerful.
If nothing of the above works,i imagine some weird video hardware issue.
To exclude video hardware issue,just run a Windows installer media or a different hash-checked Live Linux distro.
Try to narrow down your options and pinpoint what causes the error.
I really hope your machine will run ApricityOS !

I don't have the nvidia drivers installed (actually made a post about the issues they cause me) but I did get Steam to work by running this command:

find ~/.steam/root/ \( -name "libgcc_s.so*" -o -name "libstdc++.so*" -o -name "libxcb.so*" \) -print -delete

Which I got here:
https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/steam#Troubleshooting

There's additional steps to be taken if that doesn't work. Run that command again and then run this:

find ~/.local/share/Steam/ \( -name "libgcc_s.so*" -o -name "libstdc++.so*" -o -name "libxcb.so*" \) -print -delete

Or you can run it by overriding those libraries:

LD_PRELOAD='/usr/$LIB/libstdc++.so.6 /usr/$LIB/libgcc_s.so.1 /usr/$LIB/libxcb.so.1' steam

You may have to do this every time Steam updates until Valve fixes it, but it does work.

The easiest way is to remove the .firstrun.ran file from your home directory (you may have to show hidden files with the keyboard shortcut CTRL-H). If you don't want to also reset your wallpaper, you can run the following command instead: 

gsettings set org.gnome.shell enabled-extensions "['user-theme@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com', 'alwayszoomworkspaces@jamie.thenicols.net', 'mediaplayer@patapon.info', 'caffeine@patapon.info', 'scroll-workspaces@gfxmonk.net', 'dash-to-dock@micxgx.gmail.com', 'suspend-button@laserb', 'topIcons@adel.gadllah@gmail.com', 'places-menu@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com', 'drive-menu@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com', 'remove-dropdown-arrows@mpdeimos.com', 'Move_Clock@rmy.pobox.com']"

ok,let's see what we can do.
Run "Add/Remove Programs" and check if you have the "dkms" package installed.
If yes,then fire up a Terminal and give:
$ sudo -i
to become root.

and then:

I get the same error everytime my computer was connected to a WiFi that required a confirmation click or sign in in a browser window after connecting in order to get access to the innternet. Apperently that breaks the apricity-core.db. It seems to be a bug because the problem is reproducible.

So what helps in my case is the following (with working internet connection):
I go with root access to /var/lib/pacman/sync and rename the 'apricity-core.db' in something like apricity-core.db.STOP'
then I execute:
sudo reflector --age 4 --fastest 64 --latest 32 --number 16 --sort rate --save /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist
(obviously you need reflector to be installed)
next:
sudo pacman-key --populate archlinux

and then it should work again. try to make an update / upgrade in the pacman GUI
or use:
sudo pacman -Syyu

if everything worked fine you should have a new apricity-core.db and you can delete the old file that you renamed before:
sudo rm /var/lib/pacman/sync/apricity-core.db.STOP 

let me know if that helps.
Can anyone else say if these steps sound reasonable?

If you have a zip of an extension, you can install it by extracting the zip to ~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions, opening tweak tool, and enabling it from the extensions page. Extensions from the Gnome extension page can, as @Dante said, be installed from Firefox. This is because Google decided to stop supporting older NPAPI plugins around a year ago, and the Gnome extension page backend hasn't been updated recently.

Is it possible?
The answer is YES.

What You Need:
1. ApricityOS Live Boot USB Flash drive -preferably USB3 if supported- (i use "Rufus",a Windows Software,for the creation of any Live Boot Media)
2. A USB Flash drive (preferably 16GB-32GB/USB3) with an MSDOS partition table and Unformatted.
3. 2 USB ports FREE and WORKING,in your pc.
4. Know how to change Boot Order from your Bios.
5. Almost 2 hours of your Free Time.

If you meet all the above requirements, continue >

1. With your PC off,plug in both your USB Flash drives.
2. Boot your PC to Bios and choose as a Boot Device your ApricityOS media.
3. Boot into ApricityOS, reach Desktop, wait until the Installer pops up and Cancel it,
   go to Settings > Power > Blank Screen > Set "Never"
4. Connect to Internet,deny any Update Prompts.
5. Install "gparted" using Pamac (Add/Remove Software) or using Pacman, by firing up a Terminal and giving:
   $ sudo pacman -S gparted
6. Run "GParted" software, click on the Top Right Box and Search for your USB Flash Drive that will be the host for your "ApricityOS".
   Mark the Device's name  eg. /dev/sdc
   You will know which is what, by looking at/comparing all the device's capacities.
   1 TB or 500GB on a /dev/sda CANNOT be your 16GB Flash Drive. It is your HDD/SSD.
   Be careful!
7. As soon as you figure out which device is the one to Install ApricityOS, take a note and exit the program.
8. Run the ApricityOS Installation Launcher and continue, as if you were normally installing on an HDD.
9. When you are asked WHERE to install the OS,give the device's name you took note of before  eg. /dev/sdc
   >>>Make sure you did NOT choose an existing Windows Partition or a Linux Partition<<<
   Choose the Automatic Configuration,leave the Installer do its Magic.
   
10.You're Done.

Now..you wait.
Go Take a shower,have lunch,watch a movie,sleep a bit.
The Installation procedure took me 80 minutes,on an i3 4000M/4Gb ram/USB3-support Laptop.
For a moment there,seemed stuck and progressed very slowly,from 24% to 28%.
After that,it went way quicker and ended up without errors.

The first System PowerOn (booting from my newly created ApricityOS Flash drive) took a while
and i needed to give the System extra time,when i reached the Desktop.
Everything is working perfectly,but the System is slow,as it loads up everything from the USB.
It needs time.
I connected to my WiFi,did my Updates..everything worked.
The First System Shut Down took a while and presented me with a few warnings,but completed succesfully.
Second System PowerOn and things turned a bit better,
System was more responsive but it kinda Hungs for a few seconds,every now and then,during opening an App or Menus.
If you give it time,it works,though.
Second Shut Down completed quicker than before,with no errors,only a couple of warnings,but still succesfully.

I'm not sure how portable this ApricityOS USB Flash drive is,since it is configured on my machine.
Even GRUB,displays my other Operating Systems at Boot time.
But i know it works!
It was fun to see this happening!

This was mentioned in the Package Management category of the forum

Link to discussion: http://apricityos.com/forum/discussion/481/pamac-issue#latest

What's happening is because of Windows Hybrid Shutdown.
When shutting down your Windows (version 8 and Onwards),they just enter a Deep State of Sleep,that's what Microsoft uses,to trick users that their OS is powering on, extremely quickly.
Know that,this is taking place only when you are Shutting Down Windows.
Does not happen upon Restart.
The real way to Shut down Windows  completely is to hold the "Shift" key pressed while clicking on the "Shut Down".
But this will work only once .
If you want a permanent solution, you can completely Deactivate Hybrid Shutdown,
Go to Control Panel > "Power Options"  > Click “Change what the power buttons do” > click the “Change settings that are currently unavailable” > uncheck the “Turn on fast start-up (recommended)” option > Click “Save changes”.
Shut Down your System.
Now,when you boot into ApricityOS,you can have full access on your drives, again.

To install manually from AUR, it's quite simple, you just have to follow the instructions here: https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Arch_User_Repository#Installing_packages

I'll try to summarize:
1st- open terminal and write:  pacman -S --needed base-devel
2nd- go to https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/pamac-aur/ and download the necessary build files by clicking on the "Download snapshot" link under "Package Actions" on the right hand side
3rd- with nautilus, go to the directory where you downloaded the file
4th- doubleclick on the *.tar.gz file and extract it. This will create a new directory with the same name of the downloaded file
5th- go inside the new directory. Open terminal. Write makepkg -sri

That's all! 
This should resolve dependencies, build the package and install it.
Maybe you'll need a reboot for the changes to take effect, I'm not sure.

Any doubts, follow carefully https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Arch_User_Repository#Installing_packages

good luck!

Here is what I did to get autologin working:

1. as root, create or open a file named /etc/gdm/custom.conf
2. paste into this file the following: 

# Enable automatic login for user
[daemon]
AutomaticLogin=your username
AutomaticLoginEnable=True

3. restart

Can't recall where I found this, probably on an Arch Wiki page. Hope it works for you as well as it worked for me!

Hi guys,

I have managed to resolve this issue after a few days of digging around online. It seems that even though pacaur and yaourt, (even package manager before the system upgrade broke the gui) found the files it seemed like the links were out of date or just plain wrongly configured in the Archlinux AUR. 

To resolve the problem,
1: I edited my pacman.conf file using the command 
sudo gedit /etc/pacman.conf

2: add the direct link to markzz's personal repo to my pacman.conf file. So basically added The following lines

[markzz]
SigLevel=Never
Source= Http://repo.markzz.com/arch/markzz/x86_64

3: ran the install using the command
sudo pacaur -Syu Linux-vfio 

And it installed.

To get the correct link to the repo I had to reverse engineer my way back up to the parent directory of one of the broken links on the Archlinux AUR wiki. The odd part of the whole experience is that packages are on AUR but for whatever reason the links to them are not properly updated or passed properly on to the mirror lists in my ApricityOS install. However I suspect it is a wider issue with the Archlinux AUR that is not noticed because most people continue to dual boot and not realize that they can potentially avoid that by using vga/PCIe pass through or realize that it is actually a possibility especially now that cpu cores are increasing and most Intel and AMD CPUs come with the support built in.
Anyway the solution described above has worked for me and the link to the repo is correct as of the time I'm writing this.

If anyone wants to do the VGA pass through in KVM to avoid dual booting, the instructions I am following are on 

http://www.se7ensins.com/forums/threads/how-to-setup-a-gaming-virtual-machine-with-gpu-passthrough-qemu-kvm-libvirt-and-vfio.1371980/

You just need to make sure you have 2 GPUs from different companies and your cpu and motherboard support vt-d or iommu.

@javier Make sure you are connected to internet and type the following commands:
sudo su
mount /dev/sdb6 /mnt
mkdir -p /mnt/boot/efi
mount /dev/sda2 /mnt/boot/efi
for  i   in   /dev   /dev/pts   /proc   /sys   /run  ; do   mount   -B  $i   /mnt/$i  ; done
chroot   /mnt

UPDATE: anyone experiencing this issue can fix it with the following steps.

Run the following in terminal:
sudo ln -s /usr/lib/libalpm.so.10.0.0 /usr/lib/libalpm.so.9
yaourt -S yaourt package-query
rm /usr/lib/libalpm.so.9

After that everything should work fine. Hope this helps.

@nadir0900 The issue is when you run ms-sys. You're specifying not only a device, but also a partition. You should tell it to install MBR on /dev/sdb, not on /dev/sdb1.

UPDATE: anyone experiencing this issue can fix it with the following steps.

Run the following in terminal:
sudo ln -s /usr/lib/libalpm.so.10.0.0 /usr/lib/libalpm.so.9
yaourt -S yaourt package-query
sudo rm /usr/lib/libalpm.so.9

After that everything should work fine. Hope this helps.

I really want to install Sublime Text 2, but its tar ball doesn't come with a PKGBUILD. In order to build one, I read this guideline https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Creating_packages#Download_and_test_the_installation more than once, but couldn't get my head around it. Do you know of another source I could check and perhaps learn from?

/* Here are the guidelines for the noobs who wonder how to install AUR from the Terminal
1) Open your Terminal
2) Type 'sudo pacman -S --needed base-devel' and hit Enter. A list of all members will be displayed, so hit Enter again to install them. The ones you already have will be skipped.
3) Open this link on your browser:  https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/pamac-aur/ then look for the "Download Snapshot" link close to the upper right hand corner of the screen.
4) Click on "Download Snapshot" and save the tar.gz file to the folder of your preference.
5) Open the folder where the file was downloaded, then double click on it to extract its content (a single folder named "pamac-aur".
6) Extract the folder to wherever you want.
7) On the terminal, change the directory to the one where the "pamac-aur" was extracted to. If, for example, you extracted the folder to "Documents" and your username is Bill, this is the command you must type: cd /home/bill/Documents
8) Still on the terminal, now type 'makepkg -s' and wait for the process to finish.
9) Once the process is done, type 'makepkg -i' and wait for the process to finish.
10) Once the process is done, you are as well.
*/

Open Pamac (add/remove program) and search for "timeshift" (NO capital letters), it will be on the Right Tab, under AUR.

1. $ gksu gedit /etc/locale.gen
2. Scroll down the list and Un-comment ( Remove the Hashtag in front of) your desired Locale.
I will use English(US) as an EXAMPLE .     The line is this:    en_US.UTF-8 UTF-8 
****Choose ONLY UTF-8****
3. Save
4. $ sudo -i
# locale-gen
5. # echo LANG=en_US.UTF-8 > /etc/locale.conf
6. # export LANG=en_US.UTF-8
7. # reboot

Now, it should be working.

Hmm.. Probably you removed some other important dependencies, along with the ffmpeg removal.
Open up Pamac (Add/Remove program), Click on Tab "Groups" at your left > Highlight "gnome" > check on the right side now for a package called "gnome-control-center" > right click to choose to install > Install and reboot.

If your ISO image was verified by md5 hash, then it might be the software you used to create the installation media, that is causing you headaches.
Try creating your usb installation media, using Rufus (windows program).
Check again what happens.
For WiFi now, the Broadcom 4313 2.4 Ghz	adapter (Dell 1501/1504) is supported by the "Broadcom STA driver" and it is available in the distro.
Run Pamac > search  for "broadcom-wl" > Install > Reboot.
Hope it helps some.

Also, always remember to EJECT your Installation Media from the Virtual Machine, after finishing with the virtual OS installation.
If not, the program might try to boot always from the Installation Media and NOT from the installed OS itself.

Boot with ApricityOS installation media, use gparted to create all the partitions you need ( /system, /home,swap), format them accordingly.
Reboot into ApricityOS installation media, run the installer and select NOT to Format your partitions, just set the mountpoints and let the installation proceed.
Ignore any warnings and keep without Re-Formatting your partitions.
Usually, this does the trick.

Open “dconf Editor” program > scroll and find "Org" > "Gnome" > “Desktop” > click arrow to expand > find “wm” >  click arrow to expand > click on “Preferences” > Find the line “button-layout” > click TWICE on it and type this:
minimize,maximize,close:appmenu
and hit enter.
Done!
It may be hard to see what you are typing in that line, as it overlays onto what is already there, but if you look at it carefully, you will see it!
;)
PS: If you want to revert it to Default (to the right side), make it like this:
appmenu:minimize,maximize,close
and of course, the order is also interchangeable eg.      appmenu:maximize,close,minimize

@ceelight
These are the CPUs affected by the Intel Microcode Update :https://downloadcenter.intel.com/download/24661
Best thing I can suggest to the users having an Intel-based System, is to install the “intel-ucode” package and recreate the Grub configuration file, according to my initial post.
After rebooting the System, they should run this command:
$ dmesg | grep microcode

IF there are lines saying that Microcode updated early, as below example:

[    0.000000] microcode: CPU0 microcode updated early to revision 0x1e, date = 2015-08-13
[    0.105470] microcode: CPU2 microcode updated early to revision 0x1e, date = 2015-08-13

it means that their CPU, needed and already applied the update.
;)
There's also the "iucode-tool" package in AUR, that allows you to check your system for available Microcode Updates, following a specific process, defined here :https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/microcode

Ok, given the fact that your system is working fine with other distros such as Elementary and Ubuntu (probably some 14.04 LTS version, i suppose) then one thing comes to mind..
Since these distros are using an LTS Kernel, you might have to use one in ApricityOS too.
It must be that, the newest kernel is not playing well with your hardware.
Luckily, there is support for LTS kernel, in Arch/Arch-based systems.
Install current LTS Kernel (4.1.18) to see how your system will respond.
You can have 2 Kernels installed at a time, so you can check what's working best for you.
Run:
$ sudo pacman -S linux-lts
to install the LTS Kernel
and then:
$ grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
to refresh Grub with the current changes.
$ sudo reboot
and then boot using the LTS kernel.
See how this goes.
If problem still persists, you could install an even older Kernel (such as Linux-3.12) which is very close to the ones that Elementary/Ubuntu LTS are using.

You will find the solution in this thread.
http://apricityos.com/forum/discussion/481/pamac-issue#latest

Sounds like the Kernel cannot identify the SSD at all.
If you already run:
$ lsblk
and the only output you got, is your usb flash drive, then that should be it.
In most cases, this can be solved by disabling "Secure Boot"  from within your uEFI Options Menu.
If that works and you are able to install ApricityOS, you should also activate the "Trim" command for your SSD.

$ sudo pacman -Qi linux-lts

When Dual-Booting, it is absolutely imperative to install your Linux OS using the same Partitioning Scheme/configuration as your Windows installation already uses.
Meaning, if you installed Windows on your SSD, using MBR (very unlikely) partitioning scheme, then you should create an ApricityOS media that supports Legacy Boot (MBR) and configure your uEFI on your motherboard to also enable Legacy Booting (and of course disable Secure Boot)
If you installed Windows following the GPT partitioning scheme, then you should be able to use the ApricityOS media out-of-the-box, having Secure Boot disabled.
I have found that the program we use, to create Bootable media from .iso files, plays a very important role.
I strongly suggest you to try with 'Rufus", a windows program, and configure it accordingly to your machine's set up.
It offers options for creating a pure Bios/MBR bootable media, a "hybrid MBR" with Support for uEFI Systems having Secure Boot disabled and Legacy Boot enabled, or pure GPT bootable media.
See how this goes.
Also, spend some time to search and learn your specific uEFI options and Settings.
Various manufacturer's implementations use different names for the same Settings.

SOLVED.
What I did was remove the "quiet splash" option in the "linux" line of grub. In this way, I can monitor the boot process and see what is causing the "partial freeze".

If anyone is interested, this "partial freeze" was related to the message "A start job is running for dev-disk-by\...." which takes 1minute 30 seconds before continue normal boot. Browsing the internet , I found this was an error with the SWAP partition. The solution has been editing /etc/fstab including there the UUID for the SWAP partition. I got the UUID for the SWAP  partition running blkid in sudo mode.

Maybe it can help someone.

It's because your user is in the 'wheel' group. By default, users in the 'wheel' group are automatically trusted. This functionality will be changed in the March release of Apricity, but if you would like to change it now, run "sudo gedit /etc/pam.d/su" and add a # in front of the third line. The third line should now read "#auth sufficient pam_wheel.so trust use_uid".

Hmmm...

Although gaming on a VM can work, I would not recommend it. Because the graphics card in the virtual machine is only an abstraction of the physical hardware -in your case the gtx970- you cannot translate the computing power 1:1 into the VM. The computing power is greatly diminished. Most older games should work, but you have to try it out for each one. There are no certainties that the games you want to play will run in a VM.

For this case I would recommend a side by side installation. So you would not virtualize anything and could harness the full power of your gpu. But you should try out if it works in a VM for you.

The icons issue should be fairly easy to resolve:

You should see a Tweak Tool icon in the application bar at the bottom of the screen (if you use gnome). Otherwise search for the tweak tool.
In the apperance settings you will find an option Icons. Change this option to Apricity Icons. Et voilà... the Icons should be back to the default you know.


Regarding the VirtualBox error: I don't use VirtualBox, but if I have some time on Monday I will try to look into it. No promises though. WHat version of VirtualBox are you using?

Could it be that your harddrive is corrupt? A read error occouring while you try to burn an image or create an bootable usb could be an indication for a defective HDD.

I would recommend that you scan your HDD for bad sectors or that you download the image to a different location and try it again.

Maybe try rebuilding virtualbox:

# pacman -Rs virtualbox-source virtualbox
# pacman -S virtualbox virtualbox-source

I haven't personally messed with installing older kernel versions due to Arch being a rolling release it can be a little trickey. I know some people install the LTS kernel in arch which you can read about here https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Kernels#Official_packages  but I wouldn't recommend it unless you are really comfortable on how to switch back since Apricity OS supports the default kernel.

Thanks for fixing the option to auto login. Now, however, I'm being presented with a window on the desktop and when Chrome is first opened that says the keyring was not unlocked and asks for a password. I can click cancel and proceed normally, but is there a way to prevent that window from opening every time I boot? Thanks

I believe Chrome considers this a feature. Since you're not asked for a password when you're logged in automatically, and since Chrome saves passwords for some sites, it wants to make sure that you are who you say you are before it auto fills in site credentials. If you want, you can set an empty password for the Gnome keyring, but this is not recommended.

In my opinion it is all up to you. Choice is part of what makes Linux great! 

The only thing that will be slightly annoying is the amount of packages that you will updating on a regular basis since Apricity OS is Arch based aka a rolling release. Find what you like and what you don't and report back if you want some feedback or run into issues.

I would eventually settle down on one or maybe two just for the sake of simplicity and ease of troubleshooting issues. I spent a good year before I found what were my favorite things such as DE/WM, Terminal, Rolling vs Scheduled releases, etc... 

We look forward to your feedback as we plan to have Apricity OS with multiple different DE choices including Plasma. :)

Hi guys.

You can try :
cd /var/cache/pacman/pkg/  # To find packages you need to downgrade
than
pacman -U <file_name_of_the_package>  # To downgrade the package

Arch wiki says : 
This process will remove the current package and install the older version. Dependency changes will be handled, but pacman will not handle version conflicts. If a library or other package needs to be downgraded with the packages, please be aware that you will have to downgrade this package yourself as well.

Or you can use from Aur : downgrader

For more info, link to wiki page : 
https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Downgrading_packages

Good luck

I found out that the mhwd is a Manjaro thing as I posted this same question over at the arch linux forums (and got my head ripped off in the process because it's not straight arch, but meh) so I searched on how to use mhwd and found this page:

https://wiki.manjaro.org/index.php?title=Configure_Graphics_Cards

I followed the instructions by doing:
sudo mhwd -a pci nonfree 0300

It installed the drivers just fine but when I rebooted my system it froze at Starting version 229. I then opened a command prompt and did:

sudo mwhd -r pci video-nvidia

@Juvinao

The workaround is to :
edit /etc/systemd/system.conf as root

change :
#DefaultTimeoutStopSec=90s to DefaultTimeoutStopSec=10s ( don't forget to remove # )

Save & reboot

This will click from the terminal and gives me error, I know I'm doing wrong.

@Juvinao

In terminal :

type : cd /etc/systemd press enter
type: sudo gedit systemd,conf press enter ( gedit = text editor )
enter password
This will open a text file called systemd.conf
in the text, find line: #DefaultTimeoutStopSec=90s 
remove # change 90s for 10s
click on file, click on save 
close text file, close terminal 
reboot

Apricity is arch-based, so package management is handled by pacman, not apt-get. I'm guessing that the other commands that didn't work for you are also specific to debian-based distributions.
ok so how can i actually do stuff on apricity then?

Well, to install a package you can run "sudo pacman -S [packagename]", where [packagename] denotes the name of the package you want to install. To list the files in a directory, run "ls". To change into a directory, try "cd". To make a new directory, use "mkdir". If there's a particular gui application you want to run from the terminal, you can run it fairly easily. For instance, if you wanted to run gedit, you would run "gedit [filename]" from terminal.

After months (yes months) I found a solution. But it will work "only" if you can afford to re-install your Windows 8/8.1/10. If yes, let me know. I can explain.

Apricity IS Arch, just with some extra repositories, an easy installer, and nice defaults. If you already have Arch installed and are happy with your setup, there aren't a lot of reasons to switch. However, if you have a new machine or hard drive and need to install from scratch, Apricity will make your life significantly easier. Also, if you have Arch installed but aren't happy with your current config and want something that looks nice, installing Apricity wouldn't be a bad choice.

Can anybody explain me why there is some extra repositories on apricity not on arch ?

Arch has a really handy thing called the Arch User Repository (AUR). This allows users to create packages of their favorite programs for Arch without needing to be an official packager. The AUR has all kinds of packages, ranging from Google Chrome to rarely used variants of tmux. However, for new users it can be a hassle (not to mention confusing) to install packages from the AUR, since often it's much more complicated than installing a package from a repository. This is why Apricity has extra repositories: its repos have commonly-used packages from the AUR (as well as some Apricity-specific packages not in the AUR) that aren't in the official Arch repos.

Oh, that's interesting. Before installing anything, try running this:

sudo pacman-key --init apricity
sudo pacman-key --populate apricity

What solved this problem for me (Apricity OS Cinnamon dev-branch):

1. Open Terminal
2. Type command: sudo nano /etc/pacman.conf
3. Enter your root password
4. Find section [apricity-core-dev], you can also use Ctrl+W to search faster for this section
5. Change SignLevel = Required line to SignLevel = Never
6. Press Ctrl+X and save changes

After these operations you can run - sudo pacman -Syu - or use Software Updater and updates should work. I recommend that after some time you switch back SignLevel line value to Required for security reasons.
You should create this mount folder manually if it doesn't exists with Terminal (mkdir) or with File manager. Remember that for some locations you may need root (sudo) permissions to create folder.
